Name: Prosulfuron
Description: Prosulfuron is a member of triazines.

plant_translocations.content: The behavior of prosulfuron in these three weed species highlights variations in both absorption and translocation. Absorption increased over time for all species, with differing percentages absorbed after two days—8% for common cocklebur, 33% for common lambsquarters, and 26% for sicklepod. However, the retention of the absorbed herbicide within the treated leaves varied significantly among the species: 53% in common cocklebur, 80% in common lambsquarters, and 93% in sicklepod. Notably, sicklepod exhibited the highest retention of the absorbed herbicide within treated leaves. Translocation of the herbicide also differed markedly among the species. Common cocklebur translocated 33% of the absorbed herbicide to upper shoots, whereas common lambsquarters translocated 15% and sicklepod only 5%. Additionally, there were notable differences in herbicide translocation into lower shoots and roots among the species, aligning with their sensitivity levels—greater translocation occurred in the more sensitive species (common cocklebur) and less in the most tolerant species (sicklepod). These differences in absorption and translocation across these weed species contribute to the varying sensitivity observed at the whole plant level.
plant_translocations.reference: Ma, G., Coble, H. D., Corbin, F. T., & Burton, J. D. (1997). Physiological mechanisms for differential responses of three weed species to prosulfuron. Weed science, 45(5), 642-647.

method.Test Plant: - Common cocklebur (Xanthium strumarium); Common lambsquarters (Chenopodium album); Sicklepod (Senna obtusifolia)
method.Plant Grown Condition: Seeds were planted in 250-ml paper cups containing quartz sand and thinned to one per cup soon after emergence. Greenhouse conditions were maintained with a 14-h photoperiod, day/night temperatures of 26/22°C, and a relative humidity range of 60 to 70%. Two days before treatment, plants were transferred to a growth chamber with a photosynthetic photon flux (PPF) of 360 µmol m-2 s-1.
method.Chemical preparation: A stock solution of phenyl-U-14C-prosulfuron (radiochemical purity = 99.6%) with a specific activity of 48.7 µCi mg-1 was prepared. The 14C-labeled herbicide was applied with a microsyringe in 16 droplets spaced uniformly near the center of the treated leaves at the midstem position in a total volume of 25 µl per plant.
method.Received pesticide of plant: s. A total concentration of 4.2 ug of 14C-prosulfuron that contained 7,468 Bq was applied to each plant.
method.Other Information: All treatments were replicated four times.
